subject: Re: JUnit Test coverage - Statement complete
msgSnippet: Scott, For non commercial use this may be fine, for commercial use I would prefer something like JTest where after the JUnit tests have run you can  get a view
messageBody:
Scott,

For non commercial use this may be fine, for commercial use I would
prefer something like JTest where after the JUnit tests have run you
can get a view of your source where the sourcelines that have been
touched are distinctly coloured.

From an example on your website I get the impression that you only
present the coverage percentages (and perhaps the number of lines
versus the total number of lines).

QStudio for Java by QA Systems will offer a broader support for JUnit
in the next release that is scheduled for december 2002. You will be
able to have QStudio generate JUnit testfiles for you (just like
JTest) but also when adding methods to you class you can have QStudio
add testmethods for these new methods.
The output of JUnit will be available in tabular form whereby you can
select a failure or success and switch in the IDE's editor to the
corresponding JUnit test.
Also coverage based upon the execution of all tests will be presented
as a HTML view of the sourcecode (covered lines being colored
distinctly).
And you can enter your own expected coverage for methods as a
percentage. When the coverage does not meet this limit you will get a
warning for this method.

At http://www.qa-systems.com/downloads/qstudioforjava/index.html you
can download a fully functional 30 day evaluation for the Windows
platform. (for Linux and Solaris you can get a similar evaluation but
since these use another licensing application you need to request a
license first).

Yours sincerely,
Arie Roy


--- In junit@y..., Scott Vachalek <svachalek@y...> wrote:
> Hello,
>
> I am not unbiased but we have a pretty good tool at:
>
> http://testersedge.com/gjtk/
>
> It is free only for non-commercial use, but most users
> are pleased with performance and ease of use. It will
> even attribute the coverage to specific JUnit tests.
>
> Scott
>
